title: Vector-Borne Diseases
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Vector-Borne Diseases.

hook.text: Mosquitoes kill more humans than any other animal on Earthâ€”over 700,000 people every year.

buildup.text: Vector-borne diseases use insects or ticks as carriers. Malaria, dengue, and Zika all travel by mosquito bite.

discovery.text: The parasite completes part of its life cycle inside the mosquitoâ€”it needs both hosts to survive.

twist.text: Climate change is expanding mosquito habitats northward, bringing tropical diseases to new regions.

climax.text: Bed nets, insecticides, and genetically modified mosquitoes are all being deployed to fight back.

punchline.text: The deadliest animal weighs two milligrams.

quiz.question: Why are mosquito-borne diseases expanding geographically?
options: Climate change is expanding mosquito habitats to new regions
Mosquitoes are evolving to fly longer distances
International travel carries mosquitoes on airplanes
